summary: Candida albicans is a commensal microbe that colonizes the oropharynx, gastrointestinal, and urogenital tracts of healthy individuals. invasive candidiasis and bloodstream infections occur almost exclusively in immunosuppressed patients. systemic candidiasis is increasingly responsible for serious and often fatal fungal infections in humans (9) and is a major cause of hospital-acquired infections in developed countries (10, 11) echinocandins, the newest class of antifungals, were introduced in 2001. at that time they were the first new antifungals to be approved in 15 years. discovery of antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) in leukocytes and epithelia of mammals primed investigations to utilize these molecules for the treatment of infectious diseases. rhesus macaque neutrophils revealed potent microbicidal activities against bacteria and fungi, including C. albicans and Cryptococcus neoformans. selective antibody neutralization of -defensins in extracts of rhesus macaque neutrophil granules ablates killing of C. albicans by these preparations. RESULTS RTD-1 kills drug-sensitive and MDR C. albicans. both organisms were killed in a time- and concentration-dependent manner by RTD-1. however, drug-sensitive ATCC 18804 was killed more rapidly. experiments were repeated twice using three biological replicates. Killing of C. albicans by RTD-1 correlates with the permeabilization of the cytoplasmic membrane (39) exposure of C. albicans ATCC 18804 to 94 g/ml Hst 5 caused a time-dependent release of ATP that plateaued at approximately 30 min.
